title: Chapter 1: Family ‚Äî Section II
content: The Flow of Intelligence According to Rabbi Nachman, a parent who lacks compassion for their children has no portion in the "intelligence of holiness." Parenting is not a series of rules, but a continuous flow of emotional energy. You receive spiritual flow only to the degree that you give it. In the final correction, the children often exceed the parents, representing a higher step in the ladder of refinement. Rules vs. Love Rules without love are dead; love that occasionally breaks a rule is life-giving. Children respond not to your words or deeds, but to the underlying feelings . Handing a child to a guardian who lacks genuine love is, in a spiritual sense, an act of extreme harm. Raising the Teenager Teenagers are not "miniature adults" in waiting; they are adults who simply look small. The key to raising them is Respect over Love. If they feel their feelings are dismissed as "meaningless" by a "big shot" parent, they will eventually find meaning elsewhere‚Äîoften in destructive cults or movements that provide the parent-figure they lack. The Game Theory of Authority Applying Game Theory to parenting means accepting that total control is an illusion. A wise parent functions like a savvy political leader: Don't seek total dominance: Authority should be authoritative, not authoritarian. Maximize Minimal Gains: Focus on the small, daily victories rather than trying to "get everything" at once. section_title: "The Flow of Intelligence" --- The Flow of Intelligence According to

content: I. The Inert & The Volatile A family of seven children often takes on the stable, inert character of Nitrogen (N‚ÇÇ) . It is robust and self-contained. However, this stability requires a "hermetic seal" against volatile elements. It must avoid bonding with "Nitroglycerine-people"‚Äîsouls that are highly reactive and unstable. When a stable Nitrogen family bonds with a reactive agent, the result is not a stronger molecule, but TNT (Trinitrotoluene). ‚ö†Ô∏è Parental Warning: To maintain stability, you must be the primary source of philosophy/Torah for your children. If you do not fill their minds with your "Inert Truth," the world will fill it with "Volatile Lies." II. The Axiom of Respect Children need your respect more than your love. Treat their words as axioms. When a teenager speaks, assume it means something fundamental. If you dismiss their feelings as "childish" because you are a "big shot" parent, you essentially declare yourself irrelevant to their internal world. They will eventually find someone who does find them meaningful‚Äîoften someone dangerous. "One application of Game Theory in raising children is: Don't seek total dominion. If you are angry with your children, this is a sure sign that judgements are dwelling on you. Assume you are wrong. Rabbi Nachman gave said some advice which I think is particularly appropriate for raising children. One of his major principles was, ‚ÄúNot to be stubborn about anything in the world‚Äù, which in Hebrew has a little different connotation than in English. It means not to force any issue with children. Also, he said not to slug them. Which in modern day Breslov is interpreted to mean not to hit them at all but I can't imagine that Rabbi Nachman really meant that. However, it probably is a good idea to not hit at all. For Children For children let me warn you the worst thing you could ever do to yourselves is to cause your parents pain (emotionally). It's worth it to give up a lot to keep your parents happy - even bad parents. I understand there can be exceptions, but this is a general rule. One who stands alone without his family will probably fall into some trap the religious and political fanatics of the world like to set for people. This is an important principle in life. (Sometimes a parent can be lacking all parental feelings, and thus be unfit to advise his children, but in the natural scheme, one's best friend will always be one's parents.) content: The Soul-Mate Percentage The concept of a "true mate" is not binary, but a matter of percentage. While the Rambam suggests that choice is the primary factor, the Kabbalistic view is that every person has several potential mates with varying degrees of spiritual connection‚Äî20%, 50%, or 100%. Finding a mate is a deep sifting process, often serving as a correction for mistakes in previous lives. Spiritual Practical Curiosity The Spiritual Marriage The revelation of an already existing eternal bond. This union can weather any obstacle, as its essence predates the physical world. Eternal The Community Marriage Kept together by social honor and community support. It is purely biological and social; while stable, it lacks the "Holy" spark of the spirit. Temporal The Scientific Marriage Driven by curiosity, creativity, and the desire to build something new. It is the marriage of the philosopher and the creator. content: ‚ÄúAll is confounded by all-mastering time; faith dies, distrust is born; and the same spirit is never steadfast among friends; for be it soon or late, men find sweet turn to bitter, and then once more to love.‚Äù ‚Äî Sophocles The Alchemy of Love Human emotions are the most powerful forces building and breaking societies. Of these, Love is the highest of the seven lower Sephirot (forces), yet it remains a "vessel" for the higher intellectual fields. It is the only force capable of bridging the gap between the physical and the spiritual worlds. True love requires the readiness for self-sacrifice‚Äîthe willingness to give up one's life for another. The Commitment of Foundation The stability of a marriage depends on the degree of commitment. If one partner is fully committed but the other is only "committed to the perks" of the relationship, the structure will eventually collapse. Commitment provides a protective Makif (Outer Light) that wards off the challenges of time and familiarity. Divine Presence and the Klipot When the Divine Presence (Shekhinah) falls into the Klipot (Shadows), marriage can become a source of profound judgment. Many women end up marrying a "shell" of a man, bringing more shadows into the world unless they can free themselves through spiritual elevation. Conversely, a marriage between two righteous individuals creates a "revival" in miniature, allowing them to exist in God's light together forever. title: Chapter 2: Marriage ‚Äî Section VI
content: The genius of the species wants improvement of the species so promiscuous sex is not good because it is aimed at quantity, not quality. Marriage is possibly good since the mates check out each other beforehand to see if they are compatible which is in fact irrelevant but what does matter is that they convey the information true the genius of the species which knows if the female male aspects complement each other. If so, they get sexually aroused. None of this has anything to do with compatibility or character. The reason for infatuation is that the genius of the species [y echida ] sees that the male and female aspect of these two individuals complement and complete each other so the children may turn out better than either. However, there is no guarantee that this will be the case since it still depends on God's will. Promiscuous sex is evil since there is no possibility of improving the species since there is no discretion as to whether the male and female aspects complement each other. Lack of infatuation means a knowledge of the genius of the species that the children resulting from the union will not be good. This is why the Jewish Orthodox community deteriorates every generation. Even though there are no more arranged marriages, but they also aren't based on love or infatuation. Therefore, one must be very careful to marry only a person he or she is infatuated with. Even if it only a temporary feeling it doesn't matter, for at least at the beginning it has to be there.

The Spiritual Reaction Sex is the physical manifestation of a metaphysical fusion. It is never "neutral." When two souls connect without the container of commitment, the energy created does not disappear‚Äîit ricochets. It reacts against the individual like a jealous force, exacting a price in spiritual depletion and internal dissonance. But when the vessel is whole, the act becomes a mechanism of higher unification, drawing the Or Makif (Surrounding Light) into the very bodies of the lovers. Sanctified (Ascent) Sensual (Gravity) The Ascent of the Spark When the intent is connection, the act functions as a Korban (Sacrifice) in the Temple. It binds the physical pleasure to a higher root, transforming the "animal soul" into a vehicle for holiness. This draws blessing, peace, and new life into the world. Integration The Gravity of the Fall Pleasure sought for its own sake remains trapped in the "Broken Vessels." It mimics the light but lacks the heat of life. Over time, it creates an addiction to the sensation while starving the soul, leading to a profound, unexplainable loneliness. content: The Substance of Matter In a literal sense, the existence of matter is the condensed light of God . The physical world is not a separate entity from the Divine, but rather the solidification of light that was drawn into the initial vessels of creation. Because of the "Breaking of the Vessels," this light is often hidden, making the world appear solid and opaque. However, every object you see is a garment for the Infinite Light. Preparation for Revelation This world is not the destination; it is a preparation. The light that shines here is intended to purify our "vessels" (our character and intelligence) so they can eventually hold the far greater light of the Next World. Meditation and deeds do not "draw" this light down‚Äîthey simply polish the vessel. Strange Loops and Spiritual Levels The life-force, the spirit, and the soul exist on distinct levels of reality. These levels are not connected by a simple ladder, but by Strange Loops ‚Äîhidden staircases that allow for the transition between dimensions. These transitions are not accessible by "tricks" or specific practices. God hates shortcuts; the Divine Light is a gift that may come once in a lifetime or stay for a season, but it can never be forced. ‚ÄúI will have mercy on him whom I will have mercy upon.‚Äù ‚Äî The Strange Loop of Grace. So, when it says there is nothing besides Him, it has to be taken literally, that none of the things God created have any existence without Him. In a practical vein the actual existence of matter is the condensed light of God. It is not from the empty space but from the light that was drawn into Akudim, the light returned up and the vessels stayed behind and thus became solidified. Because of the breaking of the vessels later on, the matter we see doesn't appear to contain any of that light, as it would have ‚Äî if not for the breaking of the vessels. But in any case, the actual substance is from the light, not from the empty space. I have thought however that in some way there is a relation to the empty space, but it is probably not true. The real probable cause of the solidification is the very reason why there was a creation in the first place, i.e., the basic ‚Äúlack‚Äù that was in the kindness of God before there was anyone to do kindness to. So, He had to create separate beings from Himself in order to reward them with the highest good, i.e., being one with Him. So, when you look at the world around you it is accurate to conceive of it as the condensed light of God. To actually receive the revelation of the light however is in the next world. title: Chapter 1: Politics And The Torah ‚Äî Section VIII
content: The exact difference between Rabbi Nachman and the Medieval Authorities of the Torah is the same as the Difference between Martin Luther and the Catholic Church. To Rabbi Nachman and Martin Luther salvation is dependent completely on faith, and in particular faith in some saint. However, in the Catholic faith and to the Rambam we find the affirmation of man's dignity and the belief that man could aspire to be like God based on his own efforts. Yet, I would like to suggest that Rabbi Nachman is a bit different than Luther since Luther's idea of faith was negative -- it was a reaction against doubt rooted in his negative feeling about life. Rabbi Nachman's idea of faith was an expression of oneness with the Creator and affirmation of Life. It is faith in God as He is manifested in one's own heart. This is the reason Rabbi Nachman's doctrine doesn't lend itself to authoritarians that want to claim to be his representatives. However, Martin Luther is responsible for the idea of the importance of every person as an individual, not as part of a group, and no one but him can claim authorship of that idea. Freedom from tyranny of another nation was the original redemption from Egypt. Then, only freedom from another nation constituted redemption. There never was a concept of freedom from your own king until 1215. He is infinitely close to us. Approaching the Infinite Because of this paradox, no matter how close we try to get to God, there are always endless dimensions to traverse. Since God is both infinitely close and far at once (an incomprehensible paradox), the only place one can truly find God is in one's heart, where one feels God. title: Chapter 1: The Song of God ‚Äî Section II
content: The Logic of Existence Spinoza's Core Argument The core of Baruch Spinoza's proof is that God defines existence itself . Existence needs no cause because its essence is to exist. If something exists, it either causes itself or is caused by something else . Tracing the chain of causes backwards (vertically) or across systems (horizontally) must eventually arrive at a Substance that is self-causing. Spinoza argues that Substance (God) includes existence in His essence. He didn't want to define God merely as the "First Cause" (because who says the chain must end?), but rather as Existence Itself . Philosophical Refinements Hegel refined this: "Being" must contain its opposite "Nothingness," leading to "Becoming." content: Responding to Criticism The great critics of metaphysical proofs‚Äî Bertrand Russell and Immanuel Kant ‚Äîchallenged Spinoza's reasoning at its core. They argued that one cannot leap from an idea to existence . But their objection rests on a misunderstanding. The True Idea vs. The Mere Idea Spinoza wasn't dealing with ordinary ideas. He distinguished between: Idea ‚Äî A mental representation, which may or may not correspond to reality. True Idea ‚Äî The essence of a thing, which necessarily corresponds to its object. When Spinoza says God's essence includes existence, he means that the True Idea of God‚ÄîHis essence‚Äîlogically necessitates His being. The Problem of Self-Reference Russell famously rejected self-referential systems. He proposed a "hierarchical" logic to avoid paradoxes‚Äîforbidding statements that refer to themselves. content: "Spirituality is determined not by the vertical level, but by the horizontal closeness to the Light." ‚Äî The Totem of Ranks. The Coordinates of the Soul Common religious thought views spirituality as a vertical "Totem Pole" or ladder where some people (e.g., Jews, scholars) occupy high rungs and others occupy lower ones. However, the true measure of a person's soul is not their y-coordinate (rank/starting point) but their x-coordinate ‚Äîtheir horizontal closeness to the "Vertical Column of Infinite Light." A person on a high rung (born into a pious family) who remains far from the column is less spiritual than a person on a low rung (a newcomer or non-Jew) who draws closer to the light. Good and evil are horizontal choices, not vertical inheritances. Vertical Rung (Inheritance) Horizontal Choice (Will) The Station of Birth The vertical hierarchy defines only the potential of the vessel. Being "Jewish" or a "Scholar" determines which world the individual operates in, but it does not automatically yield holiness. One can be at a "high" rung and still be evil, or at a "low" rung and be righteous. Vessel Potential The Distance from Light The horizontal axis is the domain of personal will. Even on the "Left" side of the ladder, there is a right and a left. A person who is considered "evil" by communal standards may still possess a spark of goodness if their internal x-coordinate is closer to the Infinite Column than a complacent "righteous" person. title: Chapter 4: Final Ideas ‚Äî Section III
content: Though Rabbi Nachman attacked the Guide to the Perplexed, there are many principles that he gets from there, like that ‚Äútaking care of the body comes before taking care of the soul,‚Äù ( Guide III:27). Or the idea that prophecy is an extension of the power of imagination [the Guide II:38], the idea that prophecy is by an angel to all prophets except Moses [the Guide II:24]. Advice from Rabbi Nachman has to be taken with a grain of salt, i.e., what he would call Tzitzum. The mikvah may be able to sweeten judgements but what about the guy that was killed in Israel going to the mikvah and the child that died after his parent put him in the freezing mikvah of the Ari. in Safed.Even if one has had seed come out of him at night, Rabbi Nachman said it is nothing unless it came also with sexual thoughts. The reason the mikvah no longer works like it did for the Baal Shem Tov is that for him it was a time for private prayer. Now that it is no longer private it is a waste of time unless in the case that Rabbi Nachman specifically said it for. All the advice of Rabbi Nachman has to be taken in this way--think: ‚ÄúWill this action increase my devakus in God ?‚Äù If the logical answer to that question is no then even if Rabbi Nachman said it is a good thing to do, he meant it for a different situation than the one that exists now for you. However, unattachment to God as when one's mind is occupied with things separate from God, is idolatry. Yet, by faith that there is nothing besides Him, one can serve God by himself himself all things. One [Rabbi Nathan‚Äôs] explanation is that prayer for physical things is below Torah, as the sages mentioned about the student in an incident that he was praying when he should have been learning. Yet this isn't a good answer since Rabbi Yochanan disagrees in that very case and says, ‚ÄúIf only a person would pray all day‚Äù.
